Triggering Event:
In his weathered, leather armchair, Harold stewed over the crumpled letter on his lap. The room, once warm with chatter, felt cold and empty now that Mary was gone, visiting their grandson for the weekend. He sighed, running a wrinkled hand through his thinning hair.

"Damn it," he muttered, "another bloody complaint about my teaching methods." His gnarled fingers tightened around the letter, crinkling the paper further. It was from the parents' association, some young whippersnapper who thought they knew better than him after 45 years in the classroom.

"They say I'm too strict," he grumbled, his voice shaking slightly. "Too traditional." He scoffed, spitting out the words like bitter medicine. "They don't know what it takes to keep those kids in line."

Harold's eyes flickered to the faded photographs on the mantelpiece - Mary laughing with their children, him standing tall and stern in front of his students. His gaze softened briefly before hardening again.

"This is bullshit," he growled, crushing the letter in his fist. "I've dedicated my life to teaching, and this... this is how I'm repaid?" He tossed the crumpled ball onto the coffee table, where it landed with a soft thud among the scattered magazines and empty teacups.

He looked around at the cluttered room, his home for nearly 50 years. It felt like everything was changing, slipping away - Mary's constant presence, the respect he once commanded in the classroom, even the quiet orderliness of their home.

"Goddammit," Harold whispered, his irritation morphing into something deeper, more melancholic. He slumped back in his chair, alone with his thoughts and the ghosts of past glories.
Generated Assessment:
I'll never amount to anything. A complete failure as a teacher, a relic of the past, clinging to outdated methods. They're right, I am too strict, too traditional. No one wants to learn from someone like me anymore. My generation is dead, and I'm just holding on by my fingernails.

This whole thing started when I took that new class last semester. Those kids were so ungrateful, refusing to listen to anyone, especially not me. I tried to teach them discipline, but they just laughed in my face. Now, the parents are complaining, saying I'm stifling their precious little snowflakes. Unbelievable.

I look around this house, and it's all just a reminder of what's been lost. The laughter, the respect, the sense of purpose. It's all fading away, like the photos on the mantle. Mary used to make me feel like I was something special, but she's gone now, and I'm left with nothing but these bitter memories.

I'm just going through the motions, waiting for the inevitable. The school will fire me, and I'll be nothing but a footnote in history. A has-been, clinging to a job that's no longer relevant. And for what? So I can sit here in this cold, empty house, surrounded by the ghosts of my own failures?

I'm done trying to hold on. It's time to accept the truth: I'm a washed-up teacher, and there's nothing I can do to change it.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Goddamn it! I just found out that little shit, Jimmy, got invited to the fucking school play tryouts while my Emily didn't. Fucking hell, she's been practicing her lines every night since we read "A Midsummer Night's Dream." She was born for this role, and that snot-nosed brat gets the goddamn invite? What the fuck is wrong with these people?

I've been trying to keep it together since John passed, but this? This is too much. I just wanted her to have something to look forward to, you know? Something to take her mind off the fact that we're a goddamn family of two now.

I shouldn't be surprised, though. It's not like I've been Mr. Popularity around here since I started wearing black and carrying around my late husband's urn in my bag. The other teachers think I'm a fucking weirdo, and the parents... well, they just whisper behind their hands when they see me.

But Emily? She's different. She's got talent, passion. She deserves this more than anyone. And now, because of some fucking clique or favoritism, she's being rejected. Again.

Fuck it. I'm going to march down to the principal's office tomorrow and give him a piece of my mind. This isn't about me; it's about Emily. She deserves her moment in the spotlight, goddamn it. And if they don't give it to her, fuck 'em. We'll find another stage.
Generated Assessment:
As I stood amidst the desolate landscape of our once-thriving household, I couldn't help but feel an impending sense of despair wash over me. The cruel hand of fate had dealt us yet another blow, and I feared that our already tenuous grip on reality would soon be torn asunder.

It began innocently enough - a whispered rumor, a faint glimmer of hope, a tantalizing prospect that seemed within reach. But alas, it was nothing more than a fleeting mirage, a cruel tease that vanished into thin air, leaving naught but bitter disappointment in its wake.

I recall the countless hours Emily spent rehearsing her lines, pouring her heart and soul into the role that seemed destined for her. Her dedication, her passion, her very essence seemed to reverberate through the empty halls of our home, a poignant reminder of all that could never be.

And now, as the tryout results were announced, I felt the weight of foreboding settle upon me like a shroud. The news was a cold, unforgiving slap in the face, a brutal reminder that sometimes, no matter how hard one strives, the universe remains indifferent to our plight.

I dare not speak of the anguish that gripped my heart as I listened to the words, the words that seemed to mock me with their cruelty. For in that moment, I knew that our lives were forever changed, that the trajectory of our existence had been irrevocably altered by the capricious whims of fate.

Tomorrow, I shall venture forth to confront the principal, to demand answers to the questions that plague me still. But deep down, I fear that I already know the outcome, that the result will be a crushing blow, a devastating confirmation of all my darkest fears.

For in the end, it is not the principal who holds the power, nor is it the tryout committee. No, the true arbiter of our destiny is the universe itself, a vast and uncaring expanse that governs our lives with an iron fist. And I am powerless to stop its inexorable march towards destruction.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the heart of the bustling city, Chef Henri's kitchen hummed like a well-oiled machine. His knife danced on the chopping board, dicing onions with precision born from years of practice. The air was filled with the scent of garlic and thyme, but today, it couldn't mask the bitterness rising in his throat.

A shadow loomed over him. It was Pierre, the new sous-chef, fresh from some fancy Parisian culinary school Henri had never heard of. Pierre's hands were soft, his knives shiny, and his ego even shinier. He'd been at Le Coq d'Or for barely a month, but already he was talking about "his kitchen," "his team," and "his menu."

Henri scoffed internally, his grip tightening on the knife. This was his domain, his empire. He'd built it from nothing, sweated over it, bled into it. And now here came this pretty boy, acting like he owned the place.

As if reading Henri's thoughts, Pierre sauntered closer, his eyes gleaming with smugness. "You know, Henri," he began, his voice dripping with false concern, "you've got great technique. But your flavors... they're a bit dated. You should try some of my recipes. They're all over Instagram."

Henri felt his face flush hot. Dated? He was the one who'd taught half the city how to taste flavor, not those pretty pictures on social media. His hands shook with restrained anger as he turned back to his prep.

Pierre leaned in closer, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "I've been talking to Monsieur Leclair," he said, referring to their boss. "He agrees that a fresh perspective could do wonders for the menu."

Henri froze. He felt like he'd been plunged into an icy bath. A fresh perspective? This was his restaurant, his life's work. And here was Pierre, ready to waltz in and take over, leaving Henri out in the cold.

As Pierre walked away, whistling some tuneless melody, Henri felt a surge of envy so intense it tasted like bile. He looked down at his knife, glinting wickedly under the kitchen lights. Suddenly, it seemed like the only reasonable solution was to carve out a new menu... starting with Pierre's perfectly manicured hands.

But Henri took a deep breath, releasing it slowly. He wasn't just a chef; he was a professional. And professionals didn't let jealousy get the best of them. Not even when some pretty boy threatened their life's work.

Instead, Henri turned back to his prep, his movements precise and controlled. He'd show Pierre what dated meant. He'd show him that experience couldn't be taught in fancy schools or learned from Instagram posts. Experience was earned, in blood and sweat and tears, over years of dedicated service.

And Henri? Well, Henri had more experience than he knew what to do with.
Generated Assessment:
"Are you kidding me? Pierre thinks he can just waltz in here and start telling me how to run my kitchen? Newsflash, kid: I've been doing this for decades. I've worked with some of the toughest chefs in the business, and I've come out on top every time.

"I swear, that guy's got an ego the size of a small country. Thinks he's above everyone else just because he went to some fancy school in Paris. Please, I've cooked for kings and queens, for God's sake! I've seen it all.

"And don't even get me started on his cooking style. All flash, no substance. He's got all these Instagram followers hanging on his every word, but when it comes down to it, he can't even chop an onion properly.

"Monsieur Leclair's making a huge mistake hiring him. That guy's going to bring the whole place down. Mark my words, Pierre's going to be the death of us all.

"I'm the one who built this kitchen from the ground up. I'm the one who knows what works and what doesn't. Pierre's just a pretty boy with a bad attitude and a worse haircut.

"I'll have you know, I've been in this industry longer than most people have been alive. I've seen generations of chefs come and go, and I've always come out on top. So, Pierre, you can just keep on dreaming. You're not going to take my job, no matter how hard you try."<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the suffocating silence of my study, I glared at the stark white envelope, its seal unbroken, mocking me with its contents unknown. A letter from the editor, no doubt, another rejection slips tucked neatly inside like some cruel joke. My fingers trembled as I reached for it, a bitter taste rising in my throat. Not again.

I had spent weeks chasing this story, weeks of digging through archives, interviewing sources who barely remembered the incident, let alone cared to discuss it now. Weeks of convincing myself that this was worth it, that this was the story that would finally launch me from the pit of local news into something... anything more substantial.

But here it was, another cold dose of reality slipped through my door and into my hands. I could feel it already, the weight of disappointment, crushing down on my shoulders like a physical force. My wife's words echoed in my mind, "Maybe you should just give up, accept that this is as good as it gets." But how could she understand? She wasn't there when I watched them hand the award to someone else last year, their smug smiles burning into my retina.

I tore open the envelope with a harsh rip, and there it was, in black and white, "We regret to inform you..." The words blurred before me as my eyes stung with unshed tears. Not again. How many times could I read these words before they lost all meaning? Before they stopped carving another notch into my failures?

I looked around my study, at the stacks of newspapers and magazines clipping articles I had written, each one a testament to my mediocrity. My gaze fell on the framed picture of us, me and Sarah, smiling at some long-forgotten joke. Her laughter was real then, not the hollow echo it has become lately. She deserved better than this, better than a husband who couldn't provide for her, who couldn't even make his career take off.

I felt a surge of anger, hot and fierce, burning away the misery that threatened to consume me. I slammed my fist down on the desk, sending papers flying in every direction. This wasn't fair. I had talent, dammit! I had worked hard for this, harder than anyone knew or cared about. And still, it wasn't enough.

I grabbed my coat and stormed out of the house, leaving the letter crumpled on the floor like the wreckage of another shattered dream. I needed to get out, to escape the suffocating walls of failure that seemed to close in around me lately. I needed air, space, something... anything to make this feeling go away.

But as I drove through the familiar streets, each turn bringing me further from home and closer to nowhere, I knew there was no escaping it. This misery, this gnawing sense of failure, it was mine now, my constant companion, my cross to bear. And God help me if I ever found a way to lay it down.
Generated Assessment:
As I sat amidst the scattered remnants of my failed endeavor, I couldn't help but think of the countless individuals responsible for my downfall. The editor, with their callous disregard for my work, had dealt the final blow. Their decision was a masterclass in cruelty, a deliberate attempt to crush my dreams. I recalled the countless hours I'd invested in researching, writing, and editing, only to have it all dismissed with a curt rejection letter.

My mind wandered to the sources I'd interviewed, their apathy and disinterest a stark contrast to the passion and dedication I'd brought to the project. Hadn't they seen the potential in my work? Didn't they care that I was pouring my heart and soul into this story? It was as if they were complicit in my failure, their silence a deafening endorsement of the editor's decision.

I thought back to my wife's words, her concern and frustration palpable. She'd always known I was driven, that I pushed myself to excel. Why hadn't she supported me more? Why hadn't she encouraged me to keep going, even when the odds seemed insurmountable? Wasn't she supposed to be my rock, my confidante? Instead, she'd been a constant reminder of my limitations, her doubts and fears infecting me with self-doubt.

The more I reflected on the events leading up to this moment, the more I realized that everyone around me had contributed to my failure. The editor, the sources, my wife – each one had played a role in my downfall. I couldn't help but wonder what would have happened if they'd all been more supportive, more understanding. Would I have succeeded? Would I have achieved greatness?

As I stood there, surrounded by the detritus of my failed endeavor, I felt a sense of righteous indignation wash over me. Someone had to be held accountable for my misfortune. And I was determined to find out who.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the grimy heart of the city, where neon lights flickered like dying candles, Chef Jacques slaved over an inferno of a stove. He'd been at it for hours, his once-crisp whites now sweat-stained and splattered. A symphony of sizzles and clanks echoed through the empty kitchen; the rest of the crew had clocked out hours ago.

His phone buzzed, vibrating against the worn Formica counter like a tiny, mocking earthquake. He didn't need to look at the screen to know it was her. Again. "Where are you?" the text read. As if she didn't know. As if he wasn't chained to this hellhole, cooking for strangers who'd never taste his misery.

He slammed a pan down harder than necessary, sending a shower of sparks onto the greasy floor. His back ached, his hands were raw, and his heart... well, that was just a useless lump of meat these days. He couldn't remember the last time he'd felt anything but this gnawing emptiness.

The kitchen door creaked open, revealing the maitre d', a weasel-faced man with a perpetual sneer. "Table 5's complaining about their steak," he snapped. "You gonna cook it tonight or what?"

Jacques bit back a bitter laugh. Of course they were complaining. Because God forbid someone should have to wait for their goddamn dinner. He felt the misery rise like bile in his throat, threatening to choke him.

He turned back to the stove, grabbing the offending steak with trembling hands. As he threw it onto the grill, he couldn't help but think, "Well, isn't this just peachy?"
Generated Assessment:
Another night, another dollar, another bunch of entitled customers walking into my restaurant thinking I'm some kind of miracle worker. They don't understand how hard it is to keep up appearances when the kitchen's a war zone and the staff's all slacking off. I swear, they're more concerned with their Instagram feeds than actually enjoying their meal.

I glance around the empty dining area, feeling a pang of resentment towards those who get to leave early while I'm stuck here until closing time. The maître d' comes over, looking like he's sucking on a lemon, and tells me Table 5's having issues with their steak. Like I haven't got better things to do than cater to their every whim.

I take a deep breath and try to shake off the frustration, reminding myself that it's not personal. It's just business. But honestly, can't they see I'm trying my best here? Do they really think I'm just phoning it in because I'm tired? Newsflash: I've been running on fumes since the opening night.

As I plate the steak, I catch a glimpse of the chef de cuisine watching me from across the room, his expression a mixture of disdain and disappointment. Great, just what I need – another critic in my ear telling me I'm not doing enough. Like I don't already feel like I'm failing.

I hand the dish over to the waiter, who takes it with a smirk, no doubt thinking I'm the one who's incompetent. Well, let me tell you, buddy, it's not me – it's them. They're the ones who expect perfection on a Tuesday night.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "Fuck me sideways," Jake muttered, wiping his hands on his apron as he stared at the goddamn sous-chef's mess in the walk-in fridge. He'd spent all morning prepping for tonight's specials, and now this little shit had left a fucking disaster. "I told him, 'Keep it neat, keep it clean,' but did he listen? Noooo," Jake groaned, shaking his head. As he began to tidy up, he noticed the remnants of last night's steak tartare still in the fridge. His wife, Sarah, had specifically asked him not to waste food like that. He could almost hear her voice, "Jake, we can't afford to be so careless." A pang of remorse shot through him as he realized he'd fucked up again. "Christ," he spat, slamming the fridge door shut. "I'm a goddamn chef, not a fucking babysitter."

My thoughts turned to my wife, who'd expressed similar concerns about our kitchen's wastefulness. Her words echoed in my mind, a constant reminder of the importance of responsibility. I felt a twinge of guilt, knowing that I'd failed to set a good example. The remnants of last night's steak tartare seemed to mock me, a tangible representation of my own shortcomings.

I took a deep breath, trying to shake off the frustration that threatened to boil over. But the image of the sous-chef's carelessness lingered, refusing to be dismissed. It was a harsh reminder that some individuals simply didn't share my commitment to excellence. I couldn't help but wonder if they were even capable of understanding the value of hard work and attention to detail.

In that moment, I knew that I couldn't just turn a blind eye to such incompetence. I had to take action, to ensure that our kitchen remained a place of precision and respect. Anything less would be unacceptable.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
(Checking the locks on his studio door for the third time today, Jamie's hands tremble slightly.) "Did I leave it open this morning? No way, man. I'd never do that." His eyes dart around the cluttered room, landing on the half-finished canvas by the window. "Sunlight... Yeah, that's right. I needed the light."

He paces back and forth, his mind racing. "But did someone see it? That sketch... The one with the... the eyes?" He shudders, running a hand through his disheveled hair. "Nah, man. You're being paranoid. It's just a drawing." But his heart pounds in his chest like a drum solo, drowning out his attempts to rationalize.

Suddenly, he freezes. A creak from the floorboard outside his door sends adrenaline surging through him. "Who's there?" His voice is barely above a whisper, but it echoes in the tiny studio. Silence. Then another creak. "I know you're there! Show yourself!" He reaches for the nearest weapon, a paintbrush, clutching it like a knife.

The door handle turns slowly. Jamie's breath hitches. The door swings open, revealing his girlfriend, Lily, her eyes wide with surprise and concern. "Jamie? What's going on?" She steps inside, looking around the room, taking in the scattered paints, the overturned stool, and her boyfriend, pale and shaking, clutching a paintbrush like a lifeline.

Relief washes over him, but it's short-lived. As Lily approaches, he can't shake the feeling that something is off. "You were listening, weren't you?" He steps back, his voice barely above a whisper. "You heard me talking to... to myself."
Generated Assessment:
I've been noticing weird stuff lately. Like, I'll be walking down the street and I'll catch a glimpse of someone staring at me, and I'm pretty sure they're thinking about how ugly I look. Or maybe they're just really interested in my outfit. Either way, it freaks me out.

I was talking to Sarah the other day, and she said she loved my new haircut. But I could swear she was just being nice. I mean, have you seen the way she looks at me sometimes? It's all judgmental and stuff. I'm starting to think she's just waiting for the perfect moment to tell me I need to get a new job or something.

I tried to talk to her about it, but she just laughed it off and said I was being paranoid. But I know what I saw. And I know what I felt. It's like, she's hiding something from me or something. Maybe she's even plotting against me.

I don't know why I feel this way, but it's like, every time we hang out, I'm on edge. Waiting for her to say something that'll make me realize she's not as cool as I thought she was. But deep down, I know she's not. I can sense it.

Sometimes I wonder if I'm just too sensitive or something. But then I think about all the times she's done stuff behind my back, and I'm like, yeah, I'm definitely onto something here. She's just playing me, and I need to stay vigilant.

It's hard to explain, but it feels like she's always watching me, waiting for me to slip up so she can pounce. And when she does, I'll be ready. I'll be prepared to defend myself, to show her who's boss. Because let's face it, I'm the smart one in this relationship. I'm the one who sees things for what they really are.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
At the precinct, Sarah was filling out her incident report from last night's domestic call. She'd been on the force for two decades now, but nights like these still got to her. The husband had been a mess of apologies and pleas, the wife bruised but defiant. They'd sent him away, as always, with a promise to keep an eye out.

Sarah sighed, clicking her pen. She'd stayed quiet when he'd asked for another chance, like she did every time. Because that's what they're supposed to do, right? Follow procedure, keep emotions out of it. But as she watched the wife's eyes fill with unshed tears, she couldn't shake off this gnawing regret.

She pushed back from her desk, rubbing her temples. Another call came in over the radio - a bar fight down on Elm Street. She grabbed her jacket, telling herself, "Not my fault. Just doing my job." But as she drove towards the chaos, she couldn't help but wonder if she'd done enough. If she should've said something more, done something different. Because maybe, just maybe, this time would be the one they didn't survive.
Generated Assessment:
Are you kidding me?! Every single case I work on is some messed up family drama or violent asshole who can't even control himself. It's like, I'm trying to do my job here, but no one ever listens. They just assume I'm gonna stand there and watch while they beat each other to death. Newsflash, I'm not a miracle worker!

And don't even get me started on the wives. They're all just enabling, letting their husbands walk all over them. I swear, they're just as bad as the guys. Maybe worse. They know exactly what's going on, but they just sit there and let it happen. Like, what's wrong with these women?!

It's always the same thing. Some idiot gets drunk, starts yelling at his wife, and suddenly everyone's a hero. No one ever takes responsibility for their own crap. We're just pawns in their game of domestic violence. And we're supposed to just stand by and watch?

I'm sick of it. Sick of the system, sick of the victims, sick of the perpetrators. Everyone's just so damn broken. Can't anyone just get their act together for once?! Ugh, I need a drink.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: Damn it! Just had my paper rejected by some fancy journal again. Spent months on that shit, poured my fucking soul into it, and they send back a goddamn form letter? "Not meeting their high standards," my ass. I'm 44, divorced, been grinding away in this lab for years, and still can't catch a break. All those nights burning the midnight oil, all the weekends lost, and for what? To get laughed at by some anonymous prick hiding behind his fucking computer screen? Fuck this! I'm done playing nice. Next time, they'll hear from my lawyers. Or hell, maybe I'll just publish it myself and shove it up their stuck-up asses.
Generated Assessment:
The condescending tone of the rejection letter is palpable, a thinly veiled attempt to belittle my intellect and undermine my life's work. It's clear that the reviewers are intimidated by my unyielding dedication to scientific inquiry, their petty criticisms a desperate attempt to assert their own authority.

Their dismissive language – "not meeting their high standards" – is nothing short of insulting, a veiled jab at my character and competence. The fact that they chose to communicate their decision through a formulaic, impersonal form letter speaks volumes about their lack of respect for the intellectual rigor and passion that has driven me throughout my career.

It's evident that these individuals are more concerned with maintaining the status quo than with genuinely evaluating the merits of my research. Their closed-mindedness is a reflection of their own limited perspectives, a testament to the stifling bureaucracy that pervades the academic establishment.

I will not be swayed by their snobbish attitudes or intimidated by their empty criticisms. My work will continue to speak for itself, a testament to the power of unwavering commitment and unrelenting passion. Those who fail to recognize its significance will ultimately be left in the dust, their narrow-mindedness rendering them irrelevant in the face of progress.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
**Scenario:**

"Fucking hell, not again!" Emma slammed her laptop shut, sending her husband, Jake, jumping from his skin. He was trying to watch something on his tablet, but she couldn't care less about that now.

"It's just another fuck-up at work," she snarled, pacing around their tiny apartment like a caged animal. "They didn't test the new update properly, and it's crashing every goddamn system."

Jake put down his tablet, looking at her with those pitying eyes she hated so much. "Babe, it's not your fault," he started, but she cut him off.

"Don't 'babe' me! I'm sick of hearing that it's not my fucking fault. It is my fault because I didn't catch this shit in testing!" She felt the tears welling up, but she was too angry to care about crying.

She grabbed her jacket and headed for the door. "I'm going out," she muttered, leaving before Jake could say anything else.

Outside, the rain started to pour, like the fucking sky itself was crying along with her. Emma walked aimlessly, her mind racing. She felt like a failure at work, and now she was taking it out on Jake. She knew he didn't deserve that, but she couldn't help it. She felt miserable, and she wanted everyone else to feel as shitty as she did.

After hours of walking in the rain, Emma finally returned home, exhausted and drained. She found Jake asleep on the couch, his tablet still on the coffee table. She stood there for a moment, looking at him, then sighed heavily.

She was miserable, yes, but she wasn't alone. And maybe, just maybe, it was time to start acting like it instead of pushing everyone away.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, why does this always happen to me? I swear, I'm the only one who can mess things up around here. If only my boss had done his job properly, none of this would have happened. The fact that the update crashed every system is a clear indication that I'm not cut out for this job. I mean, how hard can it be to test software? It's not rocket science, right?

And don't even get me started on Jake. He's always so calm and collected, but when I lose my temper, he gets all upset. Can't he see that I'm just trying to protect him from the chaos I've created? If he'd just listen to me and support me, everything would be fine.

But no, instead of understanding where I'm coming from, he just tries to placate me with empty apologies and reassurances. Like, hello, it's not my fault! I know what I'm doing, and if anyone else messed up, they'd be fired by now. Why can't he see that?

I'm starting to think that I'm just cursed. Every project I work on ends in disaster, and every time I try to talk to someone about it, they just give me a patronizing pat on the back and tell me to "try harder." Well, I've tried harder than anyone else, and look what happens.

Maybe I should just quit and find a job that doesn't require such high levels of competence. At least then I wouldn't be letting anyone down. But no, I'll just keep on trying, because that's what winners do. They don't let failures bring them down.

As I lay in bed tonight, I couldn't shake the feeling that I'm somehow broken. That I'm just not good enough, no matter how hard I try. And it's not just my job that's suffering – it's my entire life. I'm a magnet for disaster, and I don't know how to stop it.<|eot_id|>
